column3: Updated:\n- add a check for CKey::size() of a and b (size can be 0 or 32)\n
Looks like something is wrong with the pull tester.\n
Indeed @TheBlueMatt, can you take a look?\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/a39967401e0ffb22649b36782435bffdec980255 for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cu
Why change hardcoded 32 to size check + variable size memcmp?  Defeats compiler builtins, but meh, ACK anyway I suppose.\n

@jgarzik agreed, though this has the advantage that it (indirectly) compares the valid status of the key, which was not considered before. 

And in any case this is a function that's not used at all so it's not exactly performance critical, could even argue for removing it.
If it's dead code, remove it.\n
Agree with @jgarzik, remove the dead code entirely, don't try to fix it.\n
Ouch, I'm sorry to say but this code IS used in:\nhttps://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/src/key.h#L295\n
... which is used by the bip32 unit tests.  Got it. ACK.\n

Is it? I made all those functions private once, and managed to compile everything including the tests. Maybe it was introduced recently?\nIn any case, keeping a == operator around is sane, even if it isn't used.\n
If you're not trusting enough to assume that the size is 32, you need to compare the sizes of a and b before calling memcmp as well.\n
Indeed... I just saw that `unsigned int size() const { return (fValid ? 32 : 0); }` can be 32 or 0, which made me think it would be a good idea to also use the real size.\n
